Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Large: Collaborative Research: Cooperation and Learning Over Cognitive Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cooperation and Learning over Cognitive Networks
Studies on herding and self-organization in economics and the social and biological sciences have observed that coordination among multiple agents leads to regular patterns of behavior and swarm intelligence, even when each group member shows limited behavioral complexity. In ant colonies, for example, individual ants cannot capture rich spatial information from their environment because of their limited sensing ability. Nevertheless, when the ants coordinate their activities within a colony, the group ends up exhibiting better sensing abilities. Using signal processing and communications techniques, the research studies how and why such manifestations of rational and organized behavior arise at the group level from local interactions among agents with limited abilities, what communication topologies enable such behavior, and what type of signal processing enables such formations.

This research seeks to understand and reverse-engineer the distributed intelligence encountered in socio-economic-biological networks, by investigating relations with learning and rationality over cognitive networks. The latter are adaptive networks that avoid centralized information processing and perform in-network inference and control decisions. Cognitive networks contrast with networks that rely on centralized and parallel information fusion, which are not scalable, are hard to adapt to changing topologies, and suffer from points of vulnerability and information bottlenecks. The research considers large scale networks of agents and studies how global (rational or irrational) patterns of behavior emerge, including herds, contagions and bubbles in economics. An understanding of how the biotic environment influences collective behavior in animal societies provides a real world guide to good cognitive networks, which can be used in turn to design engineered systems. Cognitive networks have applications in areas ranging from precision agriculture, to environmental monitoring, disaster relief management, and smart spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is regularly observed in nature that interaction among individual agents can lead to complex patterns of behavior and manifestations of collective cognition, even in situations where each member of the group may have limited capabilities. This type of behavior is observed, for example, in fish schooling and prey-predator evasion maneuvers. Motivated by these observations, the major goal under this research effort has been to use cues from nature to develop strategies that enable networked agents to learn in real-time from data streaming in from their environment. The resulting information-diffusion strategies would enable agents to model forms of collective behavior such as fish schooling or prey-predator maneuvers. More broadly, the diffusion strategies would enable networks to solve optimization and inference problems more effectively through decentralized interactions.

The studies in the project have been pursued in the context of adaptive networks. This is a broad class of networks consisting of interconnected agents with learning and adaptation abilities. The agents can be static or they can move. The topology linking the agents can vary with time as well. The agents are endowed with local processing abilities, and with the ability to consult with their neighbors. Through repeated localized interactions, a form of collective inference emerges, which can be used to solve distributed optimization and resource allocation problems in a robust, scalable, and decentralized manner.  

The emphasis in the work has been on developing strategies that are able to learn continuously from streaming data. Several important research questions have been considered. For example, when networked agents interact to solve an inference problem (such as estimating an unknown parameter or detecting whether an event has occurred), it is critical to understand how well they are able to learn and how fast? Do they always learn better through cooperation (see figure)? What aspects of the graph topology limit their collective learning? It is also often observed in nature that information is sensed by agents in a highly asynchronous manner. Some agents in an animal group, for example, may sense the presence of a predator while other agents may be unaware of the information. Also, some agents may disappear and the graph topology linking the agents is constantly evolving. It becomes critical to examine the effect of such asynchronous events on the learning abilities of the network, and how cooperative behavior endows networks with inherent robustness properties. It is also critical to examine the behavior of networks when clusters of agents within the same network may have different or competing interests. Extensive investigations have been carried out during the life of this project to clarify these and other related questions, leading to close to 100 journal and conference articles, 2 book chapters, 1 book, and 4 PhD dissertations.

The results obtained under this research effort have the potential to influence algorithm design in various fields where information is naturally available in a distributed form. For example, in many modern applications, data is already available in dispersed form over the Cloud, and there is an ever-increasing need to mine information from Big Data sets. Cooperation among networked agents provides one powerful tool for the development of efficient data mining techniques. The strategies resulting from this work are also useful for scenarios where it is undesirable to share data globally due to privacy or security concerns and it is preferred to perform inference by relying instead on decentralized solutions.
